One concern I have with the statement of >50% of spread being asymptomatic is that it is purely data from hypothetical models showing that. All data that I have been able to find on real world data shows asymptomatic spread as negligible and pre-symptomatic spread to be significantly lower than symptomatic spread. https://www.bmj.com/content/371/bmj.m4851

So it turns out that current SARS-COV2 tests aren't nearly as good as many seem to think (note: we test for the VIRUS not the disease COVID-19). According to this CTV News article: https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/fact-check-how-accurate-are-pcr-tests-for-the-novel-coronavirus-1.5257357 that references and summarizes this page at Health Canada: https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/diseases-conditions/understanding-covid-19-testing.html , for infected people N days from initial infection, the current gold-standard PCR test has a FALSE NEGATIVE rate of: 1) 98% where N is up to 2 days, 2) 50% for N up to 5 days, and 3) 10% for N over 5 days... including those who are very symptomatic. Further, the "quick" tests' accuracy are worse than this. In other words, getting a NEGATIVE test gives you no real assurance that you are not infected. I was pretty shocked that not only did I not know this, I asked several others - whom I consider knowledgeable - and none of them realized it was this bad. As an aside the rate of false POSITIVES is very low (approx 0.1%) on all tests so a positive result is pretty important. The upshot of this is that a negative test doesn't really mean all that much; infected people (after a 14 day quarantine period say) who test negative still have a 1 in 10 chance of being infected. And it certainly suggests we need to vastly expand testing and do it much more often.

Health care as a whole shouldn't stem on whether or not it is viable through economic means. For some very specific countries, *cough cough*, the testing should be as frequent and widespread as possible. Covid showed just how terrible people are when push comes to shove in keeping it at bay. Whatever the reason for the failure, humanity failed on something that should never have gotten as bad as it did. Or didn't, if you're one of 'those' people.

I work in a molecular biology lab specifically built for testing COVID samples, and one thing it’s taught me is the importance in healthcare and global health of having many different ways of accomplishing the same goal. We have strict SOPs but—within those—our approaches have to be highly flexible to accommodate the many types of clients we serve and fulfill each of their individual needs. PCR and antigen tests both have gaps that the other helps fill, and both are vital for different outcomes. I want to correct some misinformation and bring in some criticism to this video.
1) PCR takes a few days is a wrong assertion. The PCR reaction generally takes only a few hours to make. And most test centers send the samples at the end of the day. These samples get tested the next day, and you get the results. Therefore, you generally get the results within 24 hours not in a few days.
2) PCR is a repetitive reaction that makes the copies of the viral RNA until it becomes so much viral RNA that you can easily detect it. Therefore, claiming PCR is "too sensitive" is an invalid argument. You can easily decrease the number of copies you make in PCR, and decrease its sensitivity. Therefore the issue you raise here is solely about price, not about sensitivity.

And this is the main problem with the video. You claim to compare high and low sensitivity tests. But you aren't aware that PCR is very flexible in terms of sensitivity. Therefore, putting sensitivity in this argument is meaningless. You should've focused only on the price. Now that you mixed sensitivity, price, time, testing frequency all in one bucket, your claims are half correct, half wrong.This makes a very confusing argument for many people who are not experts on the field, and also makes them semi informed, semi-misinformed.

Solid information and reasoning, but another thing that we'd have to address is people's willingness to get tested regularly. To effectively use rapid antigen tests for community screening we'd need a large proportion of a community to keep getting tested on a regular basis, not just when they think they've had an exposure or are getting tested before they travel somewhere (which itself can be a flawed strategy). Where I live, anyone who wants to get tested can go to a community center and get swabbed for a PCR test for free, but as far as I know people aren't doing this regularly. This isn't a criticism of people's willingness to get tested, because it would certainly be a hassle to go to a testing site and wait in a long line every day or even once a week, especially if we're trying to screen a whole city or town. Assuming people would have the same accessibility for rapid antigen testing, we'd need to have a strategy in place to ensure that people are actually getting tested regularly.

For example, an effective but probably impractical strategy would be to have a rapid test that people can perform themselves, which would theoretically allow people to swab themselves each day and then isolate and get PCR tested if the rapid antigen test yields a positive result. However, unless these tests are being distributed for free or at a really low price, only certain people might be able to afford adding these tests to their weekly or monthly budgets, especially since people are still going through financial problems. Ultimately this means that we might still be missing a large portions of the population. Another possibility would be for businesses to screen customers before allowing them inside, but again this would be wildly impractical since people (myself included) would likely not be willing to get swabbed, then sit around for 15min if all they wanted to do was go into a grocery store to buy one item.

All that being said, this could be an effective strategy for community screening if a community has the resources to regularly use these antigen tests in "high risk" places (e.g. hospitals, nursing homes, doctor's offices), or for places where people are often around others for long periods of time (e.g. schools, gyms, restaurants). The optimal solution will be more complicated than just using cheaper, faster tests, but the team at minutephysics did a good job at showing how different tests can fit into our overall testing strategy.

Caveat 1 is countered by something in the video, and which is how testing for diseases is done when people are serious about actually testing, rather than performing theater: you test frequently. At five days to peak viral load (to use the numbers you reference in this video), you want to test every 3 days or so. That can be expensive, but you can test one person 20 times over 60 days for the same price you test one person once, and you're far, FAR more likely to catch him on the up-swing towards infectiousness this way. If you restrict it to contact-tracing candidates, you could test one person 1/day over 14 days for $70, or over a measly 7 days for $35, and determine if he's caught it and is carrying much more reliably and cut the quarantine time down significantly (since we know that he'd be showing symptoms after a certain point...I may be off on exactly how many days, but 7 seems like a good rough estimate and 14 is definitely plenty). Moreover, you wouldn't be saying "you have it!" based on fragments left over from having had it before, or, worse, from never having had it but having had some minor exposure that never reached infectious levels of viral load.

Caveat 2 doesn't apply; the rapid tests are effective enough, especially done in relatively rapid succession. Three tests in a row on a test that's 90% accurate will get a wrong result only 1/1000 times, so an expensive test would need to be 99.9% accurate to match that in a one-off.

Caveat 3 is actually a point I think you're spreading misinformation around: there is no evidence of asymptomatic spread of this particular disease.

Caveat 4 is also combatted by the same thing as caveat 1: frequent testing. One positive test means you take another rapid test, a few hours later or the next day. Quarantining on the off chance the false positive was real when it lasts for a day at most is nowhere near as big a deal as quarantining for a fortnight and until you test negative twice on an expensive test that takes a week!

Caveat 5 is just there for the theater. No, we'll never be "rid" of Covid-19, the same way we'll never be rid of the flu. But we'll get over it and live with it. I pent the past nine months working at a covid-19 testing lab and there are several problems with this video. A PCR test does not take multiple days. A PCR test takes about 1.5 to 2 hours if implemented properly. The reason many labs don't give you the result any faster is that the lab often isn't at the point of swabbing, that tests are batched together and that sometimes they have to be re-done. There is no good reason why a test result should ever take more than 24 hours to reach you given a competent operation with 24/7 staffing. Also, a PCR test really should not cost more than around $25. I know most of the testing companies charge a lot more than this but that's mostly because they can and because of failure to automate and streamline the workflows. Another big problem is that given the low sensitivity of the antigen tests, you would need to test people much more frequently to have the same chance of catching them during the period where the disease is detectable. You are also overestimating the sensitivity of both types of test. Even a decent PCR test can fail to catch a positive a week after infection. A negative result on an antigen test gives you no useful information other than "I'm probably not super infectious right at this moment I took the test". One of the few good uses of the antigen tests is as a verification that someone who is symptomatic truly has covid-19, however you still have to re-test with PCR if the antigen test is negative.

We should stop thinking about tests as ultimate answer, but as chance update. As described here: https://youtu.be/lG4VkPoG3ko tests basically update your chance of being sick by some factor. So if you have a test that is 90% accurate it more or less update your chances by a factor* of 90:10= 9x. If it is 95% then it updates 95:5=19x. For screening purpose, we should maximise the factor of all test. Basically divide update factor by cost (if cost is a limit, just like it is now).

*More or less, I may misremember exact maths behind that, also take into account general accuracy and not specificity and sensitivity. Just for general idea, the details should be left in hands of experts.

You've forgotten to talk about pooled PCR test which has been done in China in particular with good success and enables to get much more from the same number of PCR. Additionally, although you mention the false positive issue in the caveats, you dismiss the issue too quickly. It you work the math, in a general population setting assuming a prior (generous) 1% prevalence, 50% of the positive tests would be false positive. However, if you start repeating the testing with rapid test, your prior is likely to drop significantly leading to a lot more false positive tests. You can build a small Markov model and look at what happens if you test everybody every day and isolate the 0.5%-1% positive individuals you get every day for 14 days like has been suggested...
Finally, the larger issue is that we still don't fully understand the transmission, while the argument you make that individuals with higher viral load are likely to transmit more and thus should be detected more stands to reason, there is an alternative theory. While higher individuals with higher viral loads are likely to be more infectious, they are also more likely to be symptomatic and self-isolate. On the other hand, true asymptomatic individuals (excluding presymptomatic) are likely to have lower viral loads and even though they are less infectious, they might the ones who are more likely to transmit SARS-COV-2. Indeed, the CDC suggests that more than half of COVID-19 might be due to asymptomatic individuals. Thus, it might be more important to control the epidemic not to identify the symptomatic high viral load individuals that can self-isolate because of symptoms but to identify the average/low asymptomatic individuals that might be missed with a less sensitive test.

I think mentioning pooled testing may have been useful in this video as it can potentially counter some of the negatives of the PCR test. The pooled testing is carried out by:

1)Take a portion of the test sample from a single individual.
2)Pool this portion with other individuals from the same community.
3)Carry out the PCR test on the pooled sample.
4a) If the result is negative for the pooled sample, no further testing is required.
4b) If the result is positive for the pooled sample, carry out individual testing by using the remaining test sample

Cheaper and less accurate tests can still be good for modeling a population as long as we know how inaccurate they are, and in what direction that inaccuracy leans. For example, if we know that a test has a very low false negative rate but a false positive rate of, say, 25%, as long as we know about the 25% figure, and we're using the test enough that we have a lot of data points, we can still work out a pretty good actual positivity estimation. We won't know which of the positives are false, but we'll know approximately how many are false.

So yeah, the tests we use to diagnose and treat individuals may be very different from the tests we use to track infection rates.

A huge effect ignored here is the effect of false negatives. Rapid tests don't just miss cases, they can lead to infectious people believing that they are not infectious and there by become more reckless - even if the public health advice doesn't say they should act any differently.

This has been a major point of contention in the UK. We have been mass rolling out Lateral flow tests that provide results in 30 minutes. While these sound great, they only detect 77% of cases when done by health professionals, with their real life sensitivity being far lower. Only 30% in several cases and reportedly as low as 3% in one group. At this point they are likely to have a net negative result by giving people the illusion of safety due to false negatives compared to the positives we do detect.

So while I think that cheap, rapid tests are hugely needed, it is dangerous to start viewing their lower sensitivity as their advantage rather than their cost or speed. Slightly reduced sensitivity is a compromise worth making to facilitate faster more wide-spread testing but we it is important to be aware that this is a compromise that mustn't be taken too far as a fear the UK may be doing.

Btw I would think that from the beginning a testing strategy with many layers would be best. It would be good to have a very fast test that doesn't have high specificity (so it doesn't distinguish much between different viral infections) and might deliver false positives as the first layer. These would include testing for particular symptoms, although that's not enough. Those who are positive here would move onto another test, which can be the "rapid" antigen test, which would be the second layer. And they could be tested more than once as well. Those who go on to develop more serious symptoms or come into contact with sensitive groups can be monitored with the PCR test, which would be the third layer... and such a strategy can be modified by adding more testing strategies as well.
But it doesn't make sense to have a single one-size-fits-all test that's itself scarce and pricey. Quick and cheap and more widespread tests are better for managing a pandemic than slow and expansive tests.
Let's keep in mind that PCR testing will not give a good epidemiological picture as well, since the tested sample is not random and also it shouldn't be random. People get tested if they have symptoms, or think they have been exposed, or have to travel, or can pay more money for a pcr test, and local government policies and the availability of tests significantly changes testing... which is for example why the positive test rate cannot be used to compare different countries with different testing strategies.

PCR test takes about 8 hours lab time to be processed. It's not days slow, unless the lab is overloaded and samples needs days to be transported.
PCR sensitivity is definitely not a problem. You can exploit it to test groups, instead individuals. You mix the samples of 5-10 people into a single test sample. If the result is negative, then nobody in the group is infectious. If the result is positive, then you have to test the individual samples.

It is worth mentioning that while the rapid antigen test is 80-90% as effective as PCR, it's not like taking it multiple times will much improve its screening capacity. If the virus is present at low viral loads, there is no replacement for PCR. Seems to me that if you are interested in visiting an at risk family member or are getting ready for an operation, go for the PCR.

It seems to me that a risk of replacing a PCR test with a rapid test with lower sensitivity would be infected individuals falsely believing they are negative and increasing risky behaviours as a result. Clearly in situations where people with symptoms seek a test this would be completely unacceptable. For screening an entire population I understand this video's point about the benefits, although it seems it would be best for individuals with symptoms to behave as if they were positive even after receiving a negative rapid test result (as they would if awaiting results from a PCR test)

Worth mentioning that in medicine sensitivity refers to the "true positive" rate of a test, ie of how many people with the disease will the test come back positive.
This means that RT-PCR tests are actually not very sensitive at all, rather their advantage is the specificity, which is the "true negative" rate.

I know this is pedantic and jargon, but medical jargon is nevertheless important.

How accurate are PCR tests?

Some of the practicalities may not actually make these tests we currently have as useful as predicted.
This is a pre-print (and so not peer reviewed yet) study in medarchive asserting that lateral flow tests used widely in the UK on university students before going home for Christmas only detected 3.2% of cases present in the sampled population. https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.12.01.20237784v2
Abstract

Lateral flow devices are quickly being implemented for use in large scale population surveillance programs for SARS-CoV-2 infection in the United Kingdom. These programs have been piloted in city wide screening in the city of Liverpool, and are now being rolled out to support care home visits and the return home of University students for the Christmas break. Here we present data on the performance of Lateral Flow devices to test almost 8,000 students at the University of Birmingham between December 2nd and December 9th 2020. The performance is validated against almost 800 samples using PCR performed in the University Pillar 2 testing lab, and theoretically validated on thousands of Pillar 2 PCR testing results performed on low-prevalence care home testing samples. Our data shows that Lateral Flow Devices do not detect infections presenting with PCR Ct values over 29-30, meaning that only 3.2% (95% CI 0.6% to 15.6%) of total cases in the student population were detected, but that as many of 85% of cases tested in the Pillar 2 PCR lab would have been detected theoretically.

Also, these tests seem to be being used in the wrong way by the government in the UK at least. Being used to certify that people are safe to travel within the UK (a task better served by a PCR test) rather than as a tool for regular screening.
